From August , shielding people are still advised to continue to follow strict social distancing measures so the rules are more or less the same as the non-shielded. But they are still at higher risk. Whatmy family already bubbled up with someone  in June   Then youaposre a bit stuck. But households are only meant to pick one bubble buddy and stick with that one, not switch around. story: NewsopinionKeir Starmer: The best way to celebrate NHS nd birthday is by giving staff pay riseA happy birthday to our NHS, and a thank you to all those who have served in it - but the best praise for our healthcare heroes and their helpers would come in their wage packetsShareCommentsByKeir Starmer:,  JUL NewsopinionSir Keir Starmer shares his good wishes and hopes for the NHS as it turns  ", url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe NHS is personal to all of us. Today, on its nd birthday, we have the chance not just to celebrate it but to reflect on what it means to us. My mum was a nurse, but she was also very ill for much of her le. The NHS she served and loved was also her leline. When I remember the dedication and professionalism of the doctors and nurses who cared for her, I feel a deep sense of gratitude. It is what inspires me to fight for our health system, to ensure that kind of care will always be available to everyone. I know many others feel the same. The NHS means so much to so many. But in the last few months, as we have battled the coronavirus, it has become even more important. The impact of Covid- across our country has been devastating. Friends and families have been kept apart and tens of thousands of lives have been taken too early, including hundreds of NHS workers. At the centre of this storm, our NHS has been a rock. For every le tragically lost, many more have been saved by the actions of our NHS heroes.  I know it has been incredibly hard for those on the front line. Day in, day out, they put themselves in harm’s way to save others. We must never forget who our key workers are. For them, it’s more than a job. Their deep sense of public service and desire to help people in need shine through. They are the best of us. That’s why Labour supports those calling on the Government to make an immediate commitment to talks on a pay rise for NHS workers, and to agree this deal as soon as possible. The numbers of deaths are, at last, coming down. But Covid- has not gone away. The threat from the virus is still very real.  Throughout this crisis, the Government has been too slow. Too slow into lockdown, too slow to ramp up testing, too slow to fix the test-and-trace system and much too slow to get PPE to the front line of the NHS. The situation we saw in Leicester this week shows that the Government has still not got a grip on quickly identying and containing local outbreaks. We need to remain vigilant and do everything we can to protect and support our NHS.  That’s why Labour is calling on ministers to publish an NHS winter resilience plan, with free flu jabs for over-s, weekly coronavirus testing for NHS and social care staff, and proper stockpiling of PPE. The Government must learn from the mistakes made in their response to the virus so far and help the NHS prepare for winter. That includes facing up to the scandal that allowed the virus to ravage our care homes. We need to eliminate the virus from care homes before winter sets in.

story: NewsDoctors told me I had IBS, an hour later I gave birth to baby girl in the toiletEXCLUSIVE: Fitness-mad mum Charlotte Wheeler-Smith, , welcomed perfect baby girl in just three pushes after doing a km run, km walk and cycling sessionShareCommentsByKelly Jenkins:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsCharlotte Wheeler-Smith, Dominic and their baby Evelyn Rose - whose arrival was a complete surprise ", url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailStrange cramps had ­Charlotte Wheeler-Smith wondering what was going on inside her tummy... and nothing could have quite ­prepared her for the answer. Lawyer Charlotte, , had done a km run, a km walk and a session with a personal trainer when the niggling pain kicked in.Incredibly, her doctor made a house call to examine Charlotte, and he said it was most likely trapped wind or irritable bowel syndrome.But just an hour later Charlotte suddenly went into labour. She was about to give birth – yet didn’t even know she was pregnant. A wave of panic and mixed emotions swept over her but Charlotte still stayed cool. She phoned boyfriend Dominic – who was out on a run – then an ambulance. Dominic got back in time for Charlotte to give birth in just three pushes. But little Evelyn Rose was born breach and Charlotte suffered an umbilical cord prolapse, meaning her baby was starved of oxygen. Charlotte says: “I had absolutely no idea I was pregnant. The only signs were stomach cramps two days before she was born. “I thought I’d eaten something bad, or it was period pains, but I called a doctor on the morning before she was born, to be sure. “He visited and said I had trapped gas and IBS. Then an hour later, I went to the toilet and an umbilical cord fell out of me. I could not believe what was happening. “I got a sudden urge to push, then two little feet popped out. I was astonished, but I knew from watching One Born Every Minute that an umbilical cord coming out first is not good, because the baby is being starved of oxygen. “And a breach delivery is harder. So I knew that I had to push with everything I had. “I was strangely calm. I just knew I had to get our baby out.” Evelyn Rose was born in a corridor at Dominic’s flat in Amsterdam, where he and fellow Londoner Charlotte live. Dominic, , picks up the story: “We’d called an ambulance, but I saw the little legs and, at this point, it’s just me and Charlotte.  “I rang the emergency services back and said, ‘You’ve got to get here now, guys!’ Charlotte is standing there, holding on to the legs. She pushed once, and it was half way up the baby’s calves, she pushed again and it was up to the hips. “With the final push, the baby dropped out. Just three pushes. Charlotte grabbed her and passed her to me. She was really floppy and blue. Then we started chest compressions and tried to get air into her. “In the meantime, the ambulance crew turned up and started working on her.” Charlotte continues: “I shouted, ‘Oh my gosh, it’s a little girl.’ I’ve always wanted a little girl – a mini- me. I looked at her and she was so beautul, with dark curly hair. I shouted, ‘Is she alive ’ I really thought at that moment she was dead. Dominic had given her CPR that he remembered being taught in primary school. She was whisked away in an ambulance and we were taken in another. “I didn’t knowshe was alive or dead. Then the emotional rollercoaster started. As a woman who has just had a baby, your emotions are all over the place – I desperately wanted her to survive.” The couple – reeling from the shock of having a baby at all – faced an anxious wait to find outEvelyn was brain damaged. Charlotte adds: “Five days later, the neurosurgeon came back and said to the doctor, ‘Have you sent me the correct scan, because this baby’s brain is absolutely fine.’ She has no brain damage at all – a real miracle given the way she was born. We were so relieved, I burst into tears. We are so, so lucky to have her. She’s a dream come true. “Being able to hold her for the first time four days after her birth was the best feeling in the world. It felt amazing and so special.” Two-week-old Evelyn is recovering well and has been moved out of ICU and on to the children’s ward. To say Charlotte was stunned to become a mum is an understatement.  She had no baby bump and had been having regular periods. Evelyn’s arrival came after a worrying time for Charlotte, who was overweight in her s and feared that might prevent her having children. “I was  stone and my periods were very irregular, so I knew falling pregnant would be a struggle,” she says. In , after a diplomatic word from a friend, Charlotte joined Slimming World, started working out and lost a whopping st in  months – dropping from a size  to size -. She now writes a blog about her weight loss journey, called Slimming and the City, and shares exercise and recipe tips. In , she met Dominic on Tinder and embarked on a long-distance romance with the telecommunications company director, who has lived in Amsterdam for  years.  While they had discussed marriage and children, neither was prepared for the shock birth of baby Evelyn. Charlotte adds: “Because of lockdown, we’d been apart for  weeks, so when I got to Amsterdam three weeks ago, we had a lovely reunion. “Who could have guessed just a few weeks later we would be parents ” Luckily, Charlotte is not a big drinker and hadn’t been consuming much alcohol during her pregnancy. She exercised vigorously daily – running, indoor cycling, exercise classes – and travelled quite a bit too. She goes on: “I feel really guilty I didn’t realise I was pregnant, when I think of the things I have done while she was in my tummy.  “Crazy exercise, personal training sessions. All the travel. “I went to Dubai in February and ended up playing Uno and drinking Hennessey Paradis – which is £, a bottle – with Tottenham footballer Dele Alli on the flight. Luckily that was the only time I really drank. Drinking for me is a single glass of Prosecco on a Friday night. “I also had surgery when I was two months pregnant – a breast uplt and skin removal after losing so much weight. They did a pregnancy test, but it came back negative! “Two days before I gave birth, I started with a run, followed by a walk and an online training session. “Then I worked and cycled into Amsterdam to go to the pub. Two days later, Evelyn Rose was born. Our little miracle. I’m so, so proud of my body and all it has achieved.”

story: NewsDogs incredible transformation from looking like bag of bones with rotting fleshWhen Nicola Owst stumbled upon a neglected dog trapped in a crate in a field, little did she know he would become a rescue project that would turn her le aroundShareCommentsByLouise Burke:,  JUL NewsPoor Buddy was in a terrible state when Nicola found him ", url"News, views and top stories . Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs part of aposA Dog is for Le not Just for Lockdown, Notebook magazineaposs campaign with the Dogaposs Trust, Nicola tells the harrowing story of how she saved the le of her beautul dog Buddy. It was  April  when my friend Sally and I decided to take a trip to view a foal she’d seen for sale on the internet. Sally ran a stables with her husband Rob in Leicestershire, where I’d spent much of my teenage years living and working with horses. It was a bit of a mission to drive down the M in the pouring rain. We had to then weave through tiny B roads and muddy lanes to see this foal, but Sally was the type of person who would go above and beyond to give an animal a loving new home. When we arrived at the address, we both had a funny feeling in the pit of our stomachs. It was clear it was not a proper paddock – it was the grimmest, scariest place I’d ever been to. Two shady-looking men came out and showed us the six-month foal. I was horried to see it looked half-starved and riddled with worms. There wasn’t just one, but two of them. We quickly handed over the cash and coaxed the nervous foals into our trailer. Just as we were about to leave, I spotted an animal wedged into the back of a rusty metal crate. I crept closer to see whether it was even alive. The poor creature, squashed inside a cat carrier, was breathing faintly. His sad eyes were just slits in his bony, bruised face. It looked astrying to keep them open was causing him intense pain. I couldn’t believe what I was seeing. His fur had worn away, showing his paper-thin skin over his bony rib-cage and face. His mottled flesh looked like it had been clawed at. He was barely alive. This poor dog had been trapped in his own waste and had obviously had no food or water for days. But what really hit me was the horrendous smell – a combination of rotting flesh and faeces. His little paw pads were burnt and red raw from standing in his own urine. It was unbelievably sad. I didn’t think twice about rescuing him. I swaddled him in a towel and took him back to our x. His legs buckled from underneath him as I carefully placed him on my knee. On closer inspection, I could see he was covered in mange – a nasty infection caused by mites that burrow under the skin. I had to save this poor creature from these horrible people. ‘I’ve got you, Buddy,’ I said to him. The name stuck. We made a sharp exit from that hellhole.  I knew exactly who to call on when we got home – Ian, the local vet, who had tended to the horses at the stables for years. He examined him straight away. Sitting on the examining table in the veterinary practice, Buddy resembled a bag of bones. Ian confirmed he was a Staffordshire bull terrier, probably not even a year old. I watched over Buddy as Ian checked him out. You’d think he would be frightened of me and the environment, but I think he was relieved. The way he looked at me made me think he was grateful to be saved. The vet diagnosed him with demodectic mange. Because he’d been left in his own mess, he’d got secondary infections and his skin was rotting away. Armed with a bag of antibiotics and care instructions from Ian, I took Buddy home. That first night I bathed him gently in the kitchen sink, then I didn’t sleep a wink, constantly checkinghe was breathing. It felt touch and go at times… We took everything slowly. I introduced small plates of chicken or scrambled egg to him so as not to upset his stomach, and gave him just enough exercise in between lots of sleep. If I’m honest, the Staffy breed hadn’t always appealed to me. I had it in my head they were aggressive dogs. But I couldn’t have been more wrong. He is the most loving, kind and loyal dog I’ve ever come across.  Over the following year, Buddy grew stronger and his infections cleared up. I made a point of socialising him even in puppyhood. He was my number one in le, and he soon won the hearts of those close to me. At the stables, Sally’s mum, Phyllis, who we called Gran, had a special bond with him. Instead of running around in the fields, playing with other dogs, he’d prefer to curl up on the sofa with Gran. When she was diagnosed with diabetes, he wouldn’t leave her side until she had her insulin. He’s very intuitive. When it came to finding myself a partner, it was a case of ‘love me, love Buddy and my horses too’. I was lucky to meet Jon through work, and he took us on as a package. To find a man who was happy to love us all meant the world. Of course, we had Buddy as a guest of honour at our wedding in . He had a special outfit for the pictures – my great auntie who has since passed away, made him a fancy collar to match my bridesmaids. Our le as a family of three was going smoothly until Buddy was diagnosed with cancer in March .  It happened the same year I went through two miscarriages. It was a very traumatic time. In a way, him being ill shted the focus away from me. I channelled any emotional energy I had on him getting better. And after numerous rounds of radiotherapy and chemotherapy, he made a recovery in October . The following autumn, I fell pregnant with my son Toby, who is now three.Before Toby arrived, we got another dog, a springer spaniel called Susie, who was rescued from a puppy farm where she was a breeding bitch for three years in a shed. I still haven’t quite worked my magic on her, she can be nervous, whereas I can take Buddy anywhere, and do anything. He’s so well-behaved. I feel like I have a lot to thank Buddy for. I’ve experienced so many things in my le because of him – we’ve been to dog shows like Crufts and won awards, met celebrities like Martin Clunes and Christine Lampard, and have a fantastic circle of friends we’ve met through Buddy, who we holiday with twice a year. Who would have thought that poor, neglected dog I first saw in the cage could have turned my le around for the better

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWorrying scenes of hundreds of drinkers ignoring social distancing rules and carnage in the streets of England have sparked fresh fears of a second wave of coronavirus and local lockdowns. As Englandaposs pubs reopened for the first time in three months, police had to break up fights and deal with other trouble while some revellers overindulged on so-called Super Saturday, which one top cop said was as busy as New Yearaposs Eve. Those who were lax in observing social distancing or caused trouble have been condemned, with the scenes stoking concerns that England could see a surge in cases after restrictions were relaxed. But the governmentaposs critics say the responsibility rests with Boris Johnson and ministers over their position that it was safe to reopen pubs on a Saturday during summer, even though experts have warned that pubs are superspreading hotspots. The government has warned a spike in Covid- cases could result in more local lockdowns such as the one currently in place in Leicester. The decision to reopen pubs came under fire as photos showed hundreds ignoring social distancing in places such as Soho in central London, and revellers looking worse for wear, with some slumped in the streets, during a night out despite Covid- still posing a danger. As Twitter users hit out at the scenes, one wrote: These pictures were inevitable expected the goal when pubs opened. Are you sure weaposre not being manipulated to blame these guys for any second wave, rather than directing it at the decision makers  Another tweeted: Government lost all authority since Cummings incident, noone is listening anymore. Blatantly obvious people werenapost going to adhere to rules with pubs, as most of us know, after a few drinks most rules go out the window. Welcome #SecondWave. A third said of the scenes in Soho: I am all for people going out for a few drinks but this is ridiculous! I am pretty sure pubs were allowed to re-open but social distancing rules still apply! Thanks to this bunch of numb nuts we are probably gonna have to go back into lock down as a second wave is a definite!Similar concerns have been raised over VE Day gatherings, huge crowds at beaches, parks and beauty spots, thousands of protesters attending anti-racism and far-right protests, and illegal raves and block parties. The latest figures show the R rate range has risen above  in London – meaning cases of the virus could be growing again. In the capital, the range is believed to be between . and .. The estimated R number across the UK is said to be between .-.. In the aftermath on Super Saturday, John Apter, the chairman of the Police Federation, said drunk people are unable to properly socially distance. It was crystal clear revellers would not adhere to the one metre plus rule as restrictions were eased on Saturday, he added. Mr Apter was on sht in Southampton, Hampshire, where he dealt with naked men, happy drunks, angry drunks, fights and more angry drunks. There were a lot of situations where police had to take care of people who were so drunk they couldnapost take care of themselves. Mr Apter said: What was crystal clear is that drunk people canapost wonapost socially distance.It was a busy night but the sht managed to cope. I know other areas have had issues with officers being assaulted. Some police forces had signalled they were apprehensive about theof pubs on a Saturday and said they were expecting problems. In some places, their fears came true. Staffordshire Police Chief Constable Gareth Morgan tweeted: Drink  drunk related calls now increased signicantly across @StaffsPolice - feels like NYE - as ever majority able to follow the rules but signicant number cannot. For those working this Saturday doesn’t feel that Super...Pubs  staff prepared well for tonight, worked hard  majority had busy but manageable evening night. Overall demand @StaffsPolice equivalent to pre Xmas NYE - busiest up to midnight. In Nottinghamshire, police responded to trouble at pubs across Mansfield, Sutton-in-Ashfield, Arnold and Newark. Windows were smashed and at least one person was assaulted as police dealt with several incidents of anti-social behaviour. Four people were arrested and five pubs decided to shut early in a bid to prevent any further trouble.  Police said three pubs in Mansfield and Sutton in Ashfield, plus two in Arnold and Newark , closed. Inspector Craig Berry of Nottinghamshire Police said: Officers were quickly on the scene to deal with a number of alcohol related anti-social behaviour reports including a smashed window and minor assault. As a result four arrests were made by officers and we supported licensees who chose to close their own premises. No pubs have been closed by the police. Weaposd like to thank the majority of the public who have acted responsibly throughout Saturday, especially whilst watching the much-anticipated Derby v Forest match.  Devon and Cornwall Police said they had received more than , reports over the so-called Super Saturday, most of which were drink-related. In Leicestershire, police were granted a dispersal order to send people away from Market Harborough town centre after reports of anti-social behaviour. The order was in place between pm on Saturday ad am on Sunday. Images from Soho in central London showed packed streets into the early hours of Sunday with revellers ignoring the one-metre plus social distancing rule which was introduced on Saturday. One man who passed through the busy streets told : Walking down old Compton Street felt like wading through a Petri dish.  Photos showed carnage in the streets in London, Manchester, Bristol, Leeds and Newcastle. Rafal Liszewski, a store manager at Clonezone on Sohoaposs Old Compton Street in London described crowds in the area on Saturday night after pubs were allowed to trade again as out of control. Saturday started very easy. But you could feel tension in the air, the -year-old told the PA news agency. Around pm crowds started to arrive... quickly everything got out of control and by - pm it was a proper street party with people dancing and drinking. Barely anyone was wearing masks and nobody respected social distancing... to be honest with that many people on one street it was physically impossible.  Mr Liszewski, who is originally from Poland but now lives in Finchley, estimated there was between two and three thousand people on the street but his shop was only allowing seven customers at a time. Pubs were allowed to reopen from am for the first time since the lockdown began in late March after Boris Johnsonaposs government decided it would be safe to do so. Many reopened at am or am and there wasnapost an immediate rush, but venues became busy in the afternoon and through the evening, when trouble flared. It was estimated , pubs would reopen and customers would sink  million pints from Saturday. Nik Antona, the national chairman of the Campaign for Real Ale , said feedback from branches suggeted up to half of pubs did not reopen. Many licensees criticised insufficient notice from the government and were taking a wait and see approach, he added. The National Police Chiefs Council had issued a joint appeal with the hospitality industry calling on drinkers to behave responsibly when pubs reopened. Prime Minister Boris Johnson and government experts had urged people to stick to the rules on Super Saturday to avoid creating a second wave of coronavirus. But critics expected Mr Johnsonaposs calls to fall on deaf ears after similar pleas were widely ignored earlier in the lockdown. Matt Hancock said the vast majority of people who went out on Super Saturday in England did the right thing, and the Governmentaposs message to the public is enjoy the new freedoms, but do so safely. Asked when the Government should begin learning lessons from its response to the pandemic, Mr Hancock told Sky News: Well we are learning all of that all of the time, looking at what works and what needs improvement.

story: NewsDad of  completes  marathons around world despite living with Parkinsons diseaseEXCLUSIVE: Dad of three Alex Flynn was diagnosed with Parkinsons disease at the age of just  but since  hes tackled some of the world’s most physically challenging racesShareCommentsByPunteha van Terheyden:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsAlex cycling as part of the  trans-America challenge ", url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAt the age of just , Alex Flynn was diagnosed with Parkinson’s ­disease – but he refused to let it hold him back. Instead, the former solicitor has gone on to tackle some of the world’s most physically challenging races and has never let his degenerative condition stand in the way. Alex, now , has ­completed the ­notoriously tough Marathon des Sables in the searing heat of the Sahara Desert, pulled a lb sled across the Arctic in temperatures of -C and run  miles through the Amazon. Since , he has successfully ­completed  marathons and challenges. And the dad of three didn’t let up during lockdown either. He spent  hours a day for a whole week climbing ,ft – more than double the height of Mount Everest – using just his stairs to raise money for charity. So far, Alex’s amazing feats of physical endurance have raised more than £, for Parkinson’s UK and more than £, for charities worldwide. He says: “I have learned to accept the bad days, and give my all on the good. I want to raise £million for Parkinson’s UK in the hope of better treatments or even a cure one day.” Fitness fanatic Alex was diagnosed with Parkinson’s in  after he noticed his little finger moving involuntarily. Following a series of tests, he was told he had the incurable disease, which develops when cells that produce ­dopamine in the brain stop working and are lost over time. In the UK, around , people are living with Parkinson’s and a further two people are diagnosed every hour. There is no cure for the le-changing disease, and sufferers are forced to live with the knowledge that they will slowly lose control of their body as the ­illness progresses.  Alex recalls: “When the ­neurologist told me it was Parkinson’s, my le suddenly felt meaningless. “I was devoid of hope and my diagnosis weighed on me from the moment I woke to the moment I fell asleep. “My twitching finger was a constant physical reminder of the battle I couldn’t fight and wouldn’t win.” But after months of ­feeling both anger and ­despair, Alex realised that he couldn’t ­wallow. Instead, he focused on his work as a lawyer and ploughed all his energy into athletic events he’d planned to do ­before his diagnosis.  Alex continued training for the Marathon des Sables – a -mile race across the Sahara Desert, known as the “toughest footrace on the Earth”. During the event, Alex got lost and had to be rescued by local tribesmen. He then became seriously ill and had to pull out of the race due viral pericarditis – an ­infection of the sac surrounding the heart. Alex was ­gutted he had to quit, but still ­managed to raise £, for charity – which made him realise that his global adventures could really help other people. He says: “This led me to the MillionMetres challenge, which ­involves running, hiking, ­cycling, climbing and rowing ,km.” In , Alex ran  miles across the Alps in  hours, ­surviving on just  minutes’ sleep. And the following year, he ran from London to Rome via Brussels and Paris in  days.  In , he became the first person to cross America using four dferent disciplines – cycling, running, climbing and rowing – covering more than , miles in just  days. He also ran  miles across the Dolomite mountains in Italy and  miles of the Colorado Rockies. More recently, in , Alex took part in Fiji’s -mile Lost Island Ultra before completing the London Marathon a fortnight later. He also trained for Primal Quest in Canada – one of the toughest adventure races in the world. Despite suffering broken ribs, a concussion and a bulging disc in his spine, Alex and his team completed the challenge in four days and five hours. Later this year, he hopes to take part in Racing the Planet’s -mile six-stage ultramarathon on Namibia’s Skeleton Coast. Alex is also hoping to secure ­sponsorship to become the first person with Parkinson’s to climb Mount Everest for real – a challenge he hopes to have professionally filmed.  But in the meantime, from July , he’ll be ­running a -mile ultramarathon in  days for Parkinson’s UK in his home town of Wantage, Oxfordshire. Although Alex does his best to stay fit and healthy, the physical symptoms of his condition sometimes flare up, which he finds ­dficult to deal with. “When I have to walk like a robot or lose my voice, my world feels ­intrinsically smaller,” Alex says.  “It really affects my confidence to be a part of society ­because I don’t want the world to see my symptoms. “I know others with Parkinson’s feel this way, too.” It is this feeling that drives Alex to continue with his epic fundraising ­adventures around the globe. He says: “Being physically restricted at times has taught me to be resilient. “That doesn’t stop me feeling angry but I use that anger and hatred for Parkinson’s to do ­positive things, such as raising money for research. “This ­disease can zap your self-worth but you can keep doing what you want to do, evenit means finding an ­alternative way of doing it. “I have hope in better treatments for Parkinson’s being discovered.

Mark Adams, chief executive of Community Integrated Care, believes thousands would have been saved – and has slammed plans for weekly tests in England as “too little, too late”. To date, Office for National Statistics figures show , care home ­residents have died with Covid-. And Mr Adams’ claim suggests some , could still be alivea robust testing regime had limited outbreaks. Accusing the Government of abandoned residents, he said: “If the priority had been, ‘Let’s just test everybody that’s coming into contact with vulnerable people’, you probably would have more than halved the number you lost in a care home, and maybe even made it a fraction of what it has been. “The Government clearly started off thinking, ‘We’re all going to get this, there are going to be about , people who die’. They’re mainly going to be old people who potentially might have died anyway and they might even save the NHS and local authorities moneythey pop their clogs early’.” Mr Adams spoke after regular testing was finally announced for care home staff in England. He said without twice-weekly testing, care homes and supported living homes would be left completely unprepared for a second, third or fourth wave of the virus. He stressed that twice-weekly testing is needed to stop infected staff bringing Covid- into homes – with residents tested by local public health nurses rather than carers. Mr Adams said: “Dealing with ­vulnerable and confused people who might have dementia, that’s a horrendous experience for them to go through. You really need to have experienced nurses doing the testing now.   “Our organisation has  nurses across  locations. But a great many social care environments are run where you don’t have nursing staff – you have highly trained care workers.“The test has a % failure rate just on the science. But thenyou add the human error into that there’s a risk. The ideal scenario is public health teams would have a dedicated team who visit care homes.” Mr Adams warned the toll could rise much higherthe Government fails to also boost testing in supported living environments. He said: “We talk about the , in nursing and care homes. There’s , in supported living. “The fact that they’re in a dferent building doesn’t mean the complexity of their condition has changed. Every time the Government pats itself on the back about gradually getting its act together five months too late, they’re talking about care homes and nursing homes – they’re not talking about this army of people who are waiting to have support themselves.” Charities have also demanded beefed-up testing for agency staff. The ONS found infection rates were higher in homes that used agency staff who worked across several sites. Professor Martin Green, chief executive of Care England, added: “Regular and routine testing is criticalwe are to garner a better understanding and keep at bay this virus. This initiative needs to be rolled out to all care homes, including adults with learning disabilities and also supported living.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDozens of iconic buildings across Britain are being lit up blue this weekend as part of celebrations to mark the nd anniversary of the founding of the NHS. This weekend is marking the biggest thank-you yet not only to the NHS and key workers, but also to all those in the community whose support has helped us get through the pandemic. The events will reach a climax with a nation-wide clap at pm on Sunday when people are being asked to come out again on their doorsteps or stop what they’re doingto applaud and then spend some time with neighbours and friends to reflect on those connections that continue to strengthen our communities as we move into the next stage of the crisis. Brits have put a candle or a light in their window to remember all those we have lost to Covid-. At pm the Dean of St Pauls lit a candle on the West End portico of the cathedral in London. Landmarks all across the country have been lit in NHS blue, supported by the #LightItBlue campaign. Number  Downing Street is lit up and a candle is placed on the doorstep to remember the hundreds of key workers who have list their lives during the pandemic.Windsor Castle, where The Queen is currently staying, is also lit in blue this evening.  Kenilworth Castle is another building paying tribute to the NHS. They tweeted: Tonight, weaposre supporting the NHS and Togetheraposs Moment of Remembrance. We remember those we have lost and pay tribute to NHS staff, key workers and everyone who has played their part during the pandemic. #lightitblue#thankyoutogether.  The famous clock at Londonaposs Waterloo station is also lit up in blue, the colour of the NHS. Lordaposs Cricket Ground tweeted: Weaposre lighting the Pavilion blue tonight.On the weekend of @NHSEngland aposs birthday, weaposre joining with other landmarks from across the UK to #LightItBlue as we remember those we have sadly lost during the pandemic.The Eden Project in Cornwall, the windmill in Lytham St Annes in Lancashire, the arch at Wembley Stadium and The Royal Albert Hall are some other iconic venues to also light up blue tonight. And across the country, members of the public have lit candles and placed them in their windows in paying tribute to our heroes. One person tweeted: #NeverForgotten#LightItBlue for those we have loved and lost due to COVID . Another said: Remembering those we have sadly lost during the pandemic. Shining a light in my window #LightItBlue#ThankYouTogether. Thinking about all those who are no longer with us... Light a candle #LightItBlue#NHS#NHSBirthday, another said.  The Covid- outbreak has been the greatest challenge the NHS has faced since it was founded on  July . Premier League stars and match officials applauded healthcare professionals and other key workers before games kicked-off on Saturday afternoon. At pm on Sunday, broadcasters will suspend normal transmissions to encourage everybody to stop what they’re doing and join with othersin their streets or neighbourhoods to applaud not just the NHS and other key workers but all those who have volunteered or helped keep services and community networks going. Sir Simon Stevens, NHS Chief Executive, said: This year has been the most challenging in NHS history, with staff displaying extraordinary dedication, skill and compassion to care for the , patients with COVID- who needed specialist hospital treatment and many others besides. During this testing time our nurses, doctors, physios, pharmacists and countless more colleagues were sustained by the support of the public, not least through the weekly applause for key workers. No health service, not even the NHS, could have coped alone with this coronavirus pandemic. From bus drivers and teachers to care staff and food retailers and, of course, the public who took action to stay at home to stop infection spreading, everyone played their part. The NHS’s birthday this year not only offers the opportunity for us to say thank you to the nation, but for us all to come together at pm to pause and recognise all the work which has taken place in the last months and say a heartfelt thank you. The clap for carers at pm on a Thursday night became an established ritual during the Covid- plague – and a focal point for unity among neighbours, streets and whole towns. The idea for this weekendaposs tribute came from the newly founded Together coalition, which includes the CBI, trades unions, the Scouts and Guides. Justin Welby, Archbishop of Canterbury, said: “ My sincere hope is this weekend will serve as a powerful moment of remembrance, thanks and connection, as we come together and commit to helping to create kinder, closer more connected communities.” Others supporters include UK Sport, Clap for Carers founder Annemarie Plas and Baroness Doreen Lawrence. Ruth May, chief nursing officer for England, said: “Throughout its history the NHS has brought the whole country together, treating everyone based on need not ability to pay. So we’re honoured the Together coalition have chosen the NHS birthday to pull the country together.” Kwame Kwei-Armah, director of the Young Vic, said: “At a time when there is so much emphasis on what ides us, giving thanks and connecting with our communities is one of the things that unites us.” The last official Clap for Carers event was held on May .

Hand sanitiser was passed out to the guests and the coupleaposs witnesses had to sign the register, at St Georgeaposs Church in Leeds, with separate pens. But Heather and Tom finally wed, nearly four months after they had first intended to marry. Their original plans - a lavish ceremony in front of more than  guests at Greyfriars Kirk in Edinburgh - had to be axed because they were scheduled days into the lockdown back in March. Speaking from their home in Leeds, the devout Christians said: It wasnapost what we had planned but it was completely unique and really special. story: NewsMeghan Markle worryingly silent and struggling to cope with new LA le - relativeEXCLUSIVE: Duchess of Sussexs relative says she is has been unusually quiet with the toll of leaving the Royal family, falling out with pal Jessica Mulroney and an ongoing court case taking tollShareByHalina Watts:,  JUL NewsMeghan Markle and Prince Harry have had a dficult year, with family and legal issues ", url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMeghan and Prince Harry must be “struggling” to cope as their royal rt is played out in a legal battle, a relative has claimed. In documents lodged at the High Court this week, the Duchess of Sussex has insisted she was left “unprotected” by the Royal Family while pregnant with son Archie. It’s the latest salvo fired in her continuing fight with a newspaper over published extracts of a letter she sent to dad Thomas. And the stress of their new le is also said to be taking its toll on Harry who is missing the close bond he once had with his brother Prince William. The relative of Meghan, who does not want to be named, told the Sunday Mirror: “She has gone very quiet. I think she is likely to be feeling extremely low and probably struggling.  “The legal battle and the increased tension it’s created with the royals due to the information that’s coming out has to be putting a lot of strain on them both. “Meghan’s been a lot more distant and introverted over the last few weeks – her family is worried. And Harry must be tormented by his fractured family ties. He was particularly down on William’s birthday on June .” This week it emerged -year-old Meghan has named in court papers five friends who gave an interview to US People magazine defending her and criticising her father.But she denies authorising them to do it.  She insisted her friends spoke to the magazine only because they were worried for her. Meghan also claimed she had been the subject of numerous damaging and distressing articles, with Kensington Palace ordering her to say nothing but “no comment”. Her legal document stated: “As her friends had never seen her in this state before, they were rightly concerned for her welfare, specically as she was pregnant, unprotected by the Institution, and prohibited from defending herself.” The couple quit as frontline royals in January to move to Canada before settling in Los Angeles. Meghan is suing the Mail on Sunday for publishing extracts from the handwritten letter she sent to her father Thomas, , in August . It was written three months after he was unable to walk her down the aisle following a heart attack. The former Suits actress claims the letter was private.  The newspaper says Mr Markle wanted its content published to correct any  impression her friends had given about what it contained when they gave their magazine interviews. Meghan has identied one of her five pals, Friend A, as the person who told People magazine the letter said: “Dad, I’m so heartbroken. I love you. I have one father. “Please stop victimising me through the media so we can repair our relationship.”  In court documents Meghan claimed this was an “unfortunately inaccurate” portrayal of her letter, insisting many times she had known nothing of her closest friends’ decision to go public. Her friends now face the prospect of having to testy on oath in the High Court that this is true. Meghan is also believed to have been hit hard by her spat with long-time pal Jessica Mulroney who was caught up in a race row last month.

Clips posted online show joyful people celebrating and engaging closely with those around them. However the Government had advised Brits continue to keep one metre apart from others despite allowing bars and restaurants to reopen on Saturday July . One man, who passed through the busy roads, told : Walking down old Compton Street felt like wading through a Petri dish.  And that was at about :pm. Not much chance to socially distance even just walking down the street. Another video shared online shows a man twerking against a car trying to navigate through the crowds. The twerker is moved on but the car struggles to get through Soho as other drinkers move into the road. In each video, police officers are seen but signicantly outnumbered by the drinkers. But police had warned Saturday night would be as busy as New Yearaposs Eve for forces across England. Nevertheless, the ugly scenes sparked a furious backlash on social media. And one man shared video of groups gathered in the streets, writing: Soho lockdown is over. Another fumed: Just seen the scenes in Soho. Itaposs asthe health care workers who risked their lives trying to deal with the pandemic were just wasting their time. And Borough Market, also in the capital, was heaving with drinkers pictured sipping foamy pints. They too were bunched together on the street.  Experts predicted pub-goers would sink a staggering  million pints at , establishments across England on Saturday alone. Some opened their doors at am to accommodate the demand. But prices for beer, wine, cider and spirits were hiked as pubs, including Wetherspoons, desperately tried to make up for lost business. Nevertheless, people were queuing to get in some pubs across England. There was a wait of around an hour just to get inside The Regal, a Wetherspoon in Cambridge.  Meanwhile AE departments prepared for a surge in booze-fuelled patients by setting up tents outside hospitals to keep people socially distanced as they waited. story: NewsMan who launched dog food business with £ and sack of brown rice now worth £mJohn Burns has become one of the richest men in Wales after he went from working as a vet in Carmarthenshire to running a multi-million-pound business started from scratchShareCommentsByLaura SharmanLaura SharmanLaura Clements:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL News ", url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA vet created a £m dog food business after starting with just £ and a sack of brown rice. John Burns, , went from working as a vet in Carmarthenshire to launching his £m business and is now one of the richest men in Wales. His interest in animal health and human health in the s sewed the seeds for his niche business Burns Pet Nutrition. After prescribing medicines to poorly animals that were not curing the problem John decided to create his own nutritional pet food for dogs, cats and rabbits. In its early stages, he would sit with his family around the TV pouring cupfuls of rice into bags which he would sell from his car. His product has since become Walesapos biggest pet food business based in Kidwelly, producing around , tonnes every week. John, from Whitland, said: I thought this was going to be big news, a vet making his own pet food. Johnaposs first ever recipe and bestselling product today was developed in  using simple ingredients including chicken, oats, peas and brown rice. He spent just £ on a box of plastic sacks as packaging and said he wasnapost fussed on colour. From his initial production of two tones of dog food in , John soon expanded to  tonnes and today around , tonnes are produced every week. He said: I didnapost have proper packaging. It just came in a plain polythene bag and I designed the leaflet and a label to go on that polythene bag. So you can imagine what that looked like. It was a very unappealing appearance. As a young vet in the s, John could have been described as alternative and was eating brown rice for breakfast long before it was served up in hipster cafes. Originally from the west coast of Scotland just south of Glasgow, he arrived in Carmarthenshire in  after qualying as a vet and worked at a practice in Whitland. He said: I can remember the very first caesarean I ever performed on a cow was by torchlight in the middle of the night. Even at that stage I was seeing health problems in pets like itchy skin or ear problems. When antibiotics or drugs were seen as the answer, John would advise clients this was not curing the problem and question the cause. He said: I thought aposwell thataposs not what veterinary science ought to beapos. Not for me anyhow. I read an article about acupuncture and thought that looked promising at solving recurring health problems. John left Whitland in  and enrolled in a human acupuncture course while working as a locum vet which in turn led to his interest in alternative medicine and nutrition. He began to reasonit worked for humans, then it would surely work for dogs. John said: Basically the traditional way of eating for humans had been abandoned by the modern world and had become high in meat and animal products with hardly any cereal grains or vegetables. Part of the thinking was that many health problems had been caused by abandoning our traditional way of eating – things like cancer, diabetes and obesity. Rather like humans, obesity in pets is the most common issue affecting health. John moved back to Llanelli and began telling clients in his practice that, while he would treat their animal with drugs, they should stop feeding their animals conventional pet food.  Instead, he advised starting their pets on a wholemeal diet of brown rice, vegetables, and meat in equal portions. But after a few years of trying to get his message across, he realised the only way was to make the pet food himself. John said: It was a job to get hold of quality brown rice back then. Itaposs not like now, although even today itaposs hard finding high-quality brown rice in west Wales.Armed with his perfect formula, John criss-crossed the country looking for a manufacturer who would make the food for him and eventually found one in Llandovery in . He said: The incubation period of my business was not far off  years. I wish Iaposd done it earlier, perhaps, but it might not have been right back in the s. People might not have been ready for it. Wholesalers had initially warned John nobody would buy his product and he was advised to develop his local contacts instead.  He changed his ambitions and instead of rolling it out nationally, he drove to local vets and pet shops and sold his pet food from his car. John said: Before I knew it I had a one-man business which was doing okay. The young vet sold his practice and moved into a bungalow in Kidwelly with his we and their two young children. The family would sit around the TV putting cupfuls of food in bags and sticking on labels. He said: I had to make a go of it. I decided to concentrate full-time on the pet food business.

Australia and Canada, for example, are on the DfTaposs list but both remain closed to British arrivals.  The Cayman Islandsapos borders are still closed to people who are not citizens or legal residents. People who arenapost citizens will have to quarantine at a government facility for  days at their own expense. Direct flights to Greece are banned until July . Visitors to Austria will have to provide a negative Covid- test that is less than four days old. In the Bahamas, the test result must be less than  days old and passengers must undergo a temperature check.  In addition to restrictions, British travellers also have to worry about their flights being cancelled or changed. Airlines expert John Strickland, director of JLS Consulting, told the Mail on Sunday: A number of airlines are planning their schedules on a very short term, hand to mouth basis. Several airlines have planned flights and put them on sale, only to find that Government policies and regulatory conditions in one country or another have meant that it is not possible to operate and have then had to cancel them and go back to square one. I don’t believe airlines are deliberately or maliciously cancelling flights. The colour-coded traffic light system decides which countries are considered safe to travel to.  Green is given to approved countries, amber is for countries considered less safe, and red means passengers ing from those countries will need to self-isolate for  days. The DfT published a list of  countries and territories where English tourists can visit without self-isolating on their . It features popular short-haul destinations such as Spain, France, Italy, Turkey, Greece and Cyprus, as well as long-haul locations including Australia, Barbados, Hong Kong, Japan, New Zealand and Vietnam. China, Portugal, Thailand, the Males and the US are among the notable absentees. The FCO published a separate list of  countries and territories which will be exempt from its advisory against all non-essential travel from Saturday, making it easier for UK tourists to be covered by travel insurance while visiting. Although the FCO included most of the places named by the DfT, among those missing are Fiji, Mauritius and the Seychelles. There are also some destinations which the FCO listed but the DfT did not, such as Canada, Estonia, Malaysia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Singapore and the Portuguese regions of the Azores and Madeira. Labour branded the measures a mess and said the Governmentaposs failure to negotiate air bridges was an indictment of their failure to tackle the crisis at home. Scotlandaposs First Minister Nicola Sturgeon acknowledged there are obvious practical reasons for alignment on the issue but criticised the shting sands of the UK policy.

title: no one was expecting such an increase in demand cycling shop owners discuss surge in bike use across dundee during lockdown
story: A cycling shop owner has admitted “nobody expected” the spike in bike usage across Dundee as stores struggle to cope with demand.Shops in the city have struggled to get hold of stock such as bikes, tyres and inner tubes for older style mountain bikes and padded seats.The increase in those taking up cycling is the result of a large number of people digging old bikes out of sheds to help pass the time during lockdown, says one local seller.Mark Grfin, from Nicholson’s on Forfar Road, said: “There are some items which are tricky to get hold of – padded seats, everyone seems to want one of them, and tyres and inner tubes for the older sized mountain bike wheels.“Lots of people have pulled old bikes out of sheds and found that they need repairs –your tyres are worn you can’t patch them.“The suppliers didn’t expect to sell anything like the number of sales we’re seeing. They make everything months in advance and base their numbers on last year’s sales figures.“No one was expecting such an increase in demand.”Gordon Farquharson, from Spokes on Annfield Road, also said that “no one could have ever predicted” such a rise in sales.He said their shop – which has remained open throughout lockdown and its workers are classed as key workers – even struggled to get bikes at one point.He said: “The demand completely outstripped supply.“People were coming in and just taking what we had without trying them, on bikes anything from £ to £,.“We were struggling for tyres and tubes at one point too.“We always managed to get them from somewhere, they were a lot more expensive than out usual suppliers but we would rather that than have nothing to offer the customer.”Gordon says suppliers are now starting to sell their  stock of bikes to keep up with demand.He added: “It is starting to get better now, we’re finding it easier to get hold of stock.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: aberdeen boss urges squad to embrace excitement of one legged europa league qualifiers
story: Boss Derek McInnes has urged Aberdeen to embrace the ‘excitement’ of one legged Euro ties after fears UEFA could scrap the qualiers.The Dons enter the first round of qualiers on August  with the draw set for August .UEFA recently confirmed qualiers would be reduced to one off games to avoid fixture congestion following the shutdown of football due to the global Covid- pandemicOne solution being discussed by UEFA was potentially scrapping the qualying rounds.McInnes is relieved the Euro bid remains alive and aims to make the most of it.He said: “It will certainly be exciting in Europe with that one legged format.“Having the one off games in the Europa League qualiers makes for proper cup football.“With it being just one leg there is no room for error.“Having so much at stake over just  minutes  is a dferent dynamic.“However domestically we have that where  ties are played to a finish.“The good thing for us isthe Premiership seasonis up and running we will have a few games to be ready for that match in the Europa League.#Following a meeting of UEFA’s Executive Committee last month European football’s governing body released the blueprint for the upcoming season.Last season#s Europa League and Champions League were both suspended at the last  stage when football was shutdown.Both competitions will be played to a finish in Germanyand Portugalin August.To get the - season up and running without impacting on the group stages UEFA took the step of making qualiers one legged.Askedthere were concerns the qualiers could be scrapped, McInnes said: “Yes. That was something a lot of us considered.“Given everything that has gone clubs will just be glad it’s happening atall.“The fact things have improved over the last few weeks is allowing us to still have this competition.“But it is still a long way to go yet before we get to August .“Hopefully things keep moving in the right direction so that we can play the tournament.”With the first three qualying rounds up to the play-offs now one legged the Reds will need the luck of the draw to land a Pittodrie tie.Home advantage in the all or nothing tie will be determined by the first team out of the hat in the draw.Aberdeen had initially been scheduled to kick off their Europa League on July  but that entry has been pushed back seven weeks due to Covid-.McInnes and his squad, along with Motherwell, will discover their first qualying round opponents at the UEFA draw on Monday August .The draw for the second round, where Premiership runners-up Rangers enter, will be made on Monday August .The Europa League second round will be played on September  with the third round on September  and play off on October .McInnes recently said he hoped there would be some financial assistance from UEFA for clubs drawn away from home in the one legged ties.Away trips will bring the expenditure of flights and hotel stays without the chance to offset that spend by home gate income.Any home games in the qualiers for Aberdeen will be played behind closed doors.Aberdeen hope to have as many as , supporters back to Pittodrie in October, after the Europa League qualiers,the Scottish Government’s easing of lockdown restrictions allow.However Scotland’s Fist Minister Nicola Sturgeon has urged caution over October for the phasedof fans.McInnes said: “One legged ties is something that was mooted a few weeks ago.“Obviously the Europa League has still to be concluded from last season.“There is also the fact that games that are normally played in June and July will now be in the back end of August.“One legged ties kind of makes sense and was expected to be honest.“It will be a dferent competition in the early stages because of that.”McInnes will attempt to lead Aberdeen into the group stages of the Europa League for the first time in seven attempts next season.In the previous six years the Reds have fallen at the third qualying round five times and exited at the second qualying stage once, to English Premier League Burnley.In preparation for the new season Aberdeen signed winger Jonny Hayes on a two year contract following his exit from Celtic.A deal for Hayes, , could only be completed because the Republic of Ireland international offered to defer his wages for a year.Due to the Covid- pandemic and predicted £m losses McInnes is for now unable to bring in new signings.It could be a case of one out for one to come inthe Reds sell a player although the club are adamant there will be no fire-sale despite the losses during the coronavirus shutdown.McInnnes is confident he will have a strong squad next season.He said: “With a clean bill of health I feel we can go and compete and achieve what we want to this season.”For as little as £. a month you can access title: letters to the editor june 5 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Thank you for publishing the informative article in your May  edition about the ongoing consultation for the old Kilmartin church building, which runs to June .We would like to remind readers, particularly those who live in Slockavullin, Ford, Bridgend and Kilmichael Glassary and all the homes in between, that the consultation is for everyone who lives in the Dunadd area.So please share your views # http:dunadd.scot church  and then click #Register Your Opinion#.Gary Linstead, Dunadd Community Enterprise.Sir,Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulancemarked its seventh anniversary on May .I look back with pride and gratitude on a service that has saved and improved thousands of lives and on the organisations, communities, businesses and iniduals across Scotland who helped launch and sustain that service.None of us could have foreseen the situation we find ourselves in, as we reach this landmark seventh birthday. This is a challenging operational environment for our aircrew and an extremely dficult period for our fundraising teams as the restrictions are preventing all the events, talks and activities taking place which are so essential to help support the country#s only charity-funded helicopter air ambulance service.It costs around £ million each year to fund our Perth and Aberdeen-based helicopter air ambulances. Every penny needed to keep these two lesavers in the air seven days a week,  days a year, is donated by the people of Scotland. We receive no statutory government funding.Yet, as I reflect on how the Scottish public has risen to every request we have made of them over the past seven years, I feel confident they will not abandon #The People#s Helicopter# at this particular time of need.Please support SCAAyou can and help us celebrate the seventh anniversary of this lesaving service # your service.John Bullough, Chairman, Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulance, Perth Airport.Sir,Volunteers are always important. But in challenging times, when our communities need them most, they are invaluable.During Volunteers# Week # June  to June  # I am so proud of the Scout volunteers in Scotland. Together they are helping tens of thousands of young people gain skills for le # helping them speak up, play their part and find their place in the world.To keep everyone safe, Scouts aren#t able to meet face to face. But this hasn#t stopped our volunteers from supporting young people. So many of our brilliant leaders are still running meetings online, helping Scouts catch up with their friends and continue to earn their awards.At a time when our children#s lives are so badly disrupted, these sessions are providing a sense of normality and continuity that#s so important for their well-being. We have also been supporting families across Scotland and beyond with free resources at scouts.org.uk the-great-indoors.I#d like to say a huge thank you to all our volunteers, whether you drive the minibus, make the drinks, look after the accounts or help deliver vital skills for le. We couldn’t do it without you. Your kindness and resilience in these tough times is inspiring and is making a dference.Andrew Sharkey, chief commissioner, Scouts ScotlandAlison Macdonald replied: #Lockdown has made me realise I took the little things for granted, being able to visit family and friends whenever I like, going out for lunch, celebrating occasions and just being able to go for a drive because I can. But seeing how our wee community comes together in times of need is always inspiring. Everything from businesses volunteers adapting to supply frontline workers with much-needed supplies, to people volunteering to collect shopping and essentials for people shielding. It#s made me realise community spirit is still very much alive in Lochgilphead and all over Mid Argyll.#Belinda Braithwaite posted: #That I can find joy in small things such as the birds and connections with friends and the community. And that nature didn’t know we were in lockdown and spring sprung into le.#Duncan Black said: #What it#s made me realise is just how many people evidently long to be in Stasi-esque organisations and just how easily tyranny can be implemented under the excuse of fear or political pandering.#Fyonna Doe responded: #Not to take anything for granted, especially seeing my family and friends, going for lunches, getting my hair done # everyday things that were the norm until the lockdown.#Niamh Rodden posted: #To not take anyone or anything for granted, especially seeing family and friends. It never seemed like a big deal till now when you aren#t able to do so, especially when you have small children and grandparents are missing out on so much. But we are all keeping each other safe. Stay home unless it#s completely necessary, stay safe and hopefully the day we get to see family again won’t be far away.#Karen Pickering said: #That people do care. I never realised how much I took seeing family and friends for granted until now.#Morag Macdonald replied: #My home is my safe place and I would be in a mess without the care of my husband. How much I miss my family and how I need to hug them.#Cathie Wilson responded: #I miss my family and I can honestly put up with hubbys weird singing noises!#

title: mid argyll youth footballers show promise in strong league
story: Bruce WestUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThis was the Lochgilphead youngsters# fourth season playing -aside football.After two seasons in the Dumbarton League, finishing second then first in the league and winning the league cup both years, the boys moved to the Glasgow League in - finishing in the top half of a very competitive Division A and making it to the final of the league cup.Another competitive season was anticipated with five new teams joining the A Division.The season started well, with Star winning all three of their league cup group games against Cambuslang Reds, Cumbernauld Colts and Glasgow Red Star -, - and -.With Cambuslang Reds and Cumbernauld Colts being new opponents this was a good start and Star qualied for the knockout stages. But the COVID- lockdown interrupted proceedings.This season’s Scottish Cup was a bit of a disappointment with Star exiting the competition in the second round after losing out to a vastly improved Dumbarton United side -. On the plus side, the first round saw Star take on Paisley League team Pollok FC and an excellent performance saw Star run out convincing winners -, one of only four defeats suffered by Pollok in all competitions.In the West Region Cup, Star progressed to the quarter-final again. A first round bye, a convincing - win against Cambuslang FA then a walkover saw the Lochgilphead youths face Paisley League A Division team Erskine.In a hard-fought encounter, Star matched Erskine for most of the game but with only  players available they couldn’t get the breakthrough they needed and eventually lost -.Star started their league campaign in September with a competitive match against new team Thorn, who transferred from Paisley A Division. Star lost -.Two strong performances in October saw Star record  a terric - win over Shettleston, last season’s league runners up, and a - win against St Patrick’s Sports Academy # an entertaining but nerve-wracking game.A mid-season stutter in November saw the Lochgilphead boys lose out to Cathcart -, then Clydebank -, both newcomers.The losing run continued into early December as Star faced last season’s champions Drumchapel Amateurs ending up down - at half-time before recovering their form with a committed second half display to pull it back to -. Unfortunately they lost out to a fourth Drumchapel goal as they chased the winner themselves.This set Star back on track as they finished the year with a hugely convincing performance, demolishing Cathcart -.January and February proved a real battle with the weather with wind, rain and freezing temperatures # often all three # only allowing four games to take place. Star secured fine victories over Busby, -, and Glasgow Red Star, -, and fought back to grind out creditable draws with Shettleston, -, and Place Park, another new team, -.Star played one league game in March before lockdown and again it was another entertaining game with a rollercoaster feel to it. Facing up to Drumchapel Amateurs, both teams played out another terric match which had everything.Coming back from a goal down and with only  men, Star played cracking football to race into a - lead but it took its toll as Drumchapel stuck to their task to draw level before adding a couple more goals to secure a win in the final five minutes.This was another fine season for Red Star s, competing well in a strong league, with only  signed players.Though the season was cut short, the boys played  games winning , drawing two and losing seven. They scored  goals and conceded  goals. There were some cracking games and the boys were looking forward to the knock-out stages of the league cup.Inconsistency probably cost Star a few more wins, but that’s what youth football development is all about and there is potential for the boys to develop.Well done from coaches and parents to the  boys who played this season – Craig Aitken, Zak Barclay, Gregor Brown, Keiran Caskie, Lewis Curran, Ruaridh Green, Woody Hoad, Alexander McLean, Conner McMurchy, Leon Murphy, Innes Paterson, Jamie Stewart and Tom West.Thanks for great support goes to sponsors Ardrishaig Community Trust, main strip, SC Crawford Building Contractors Limited, change strip and zip tops, Jewsons, tracksuits, and Mid Argyll Youth Development Services and the parents, supporters, referees and opposition teams that have made the season so enjoyable.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I would like to take this opportunity to thank volunteers for all their help and hard work over the lockdown period.Volunteering groups have been amazing and I have personal experience of the support offered by Team Tarbert to enable others to stay safely at home.The volunteers have been compassionate and reassuring and every visit the volunteer has a cheery smile and happy wave.Thank you to all volunteers. It shows contempt for those in the NHS who have risked their lives to save others. It shows contempt for those who have died without their loved ones by their side. It shows contempt for all of us who have stuck by the rules to protect our lives and the lives of others.Boris Johnson has asked us to #move on# but this issue will not go away. This is a wound that will continue to fester.Dominic Cummings continues to be a major player in government decisions and rules, those rules he so shamelessly flaunted without even an apology. He should have had the humility and integrity to resign, or been sacked by the Prime Minister.Marion Lacey, Lochgair.Sir,Organised by Scottish Land and Estates , the annual Helping it Happen Awards, which are free to enter, showcase the work done in   by businesses, farms and estates to help rural Scotland thrive.We have heard of so many wonderful examples of people working together during the COVID- pandemic, so we are especially encouraging entries to our new #Community Champion of the Year# category.If you have helped your community during the pandemic, ersied your business, are doing innovative work on your farm or perhaps you have been doing some really important work in conservation, the environment or educating youngsters about rural Scotland, you should enter # or nominate someone .The Helping it Happen Awards are sponsored by GLM and there will be a Community Champion of the Year award across five Scottish regions: North East, Highland, Central Scotland, South West and South East.To enter, visit tie SLE website or search for #Helping it Happen Awards# online. title: letters to the editor june 26 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,In publishing the opinion piece #All lives matter# from your contributor on page  of the June  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser, you have demonstrated a profound lack of understanding of the current Black Lives Matter protests.The tone-deaf piece is an attempt by your contributor to shut down engagement and perpetuate ignorance.How anybody can make the claim that all lives matter after witnessing such horric police brutality is beyond belief.All lives cannot matter until Black Lives Matter.Instead of deflecting and diluting the conversation, surely it is time to educate ourselves about what is happening, and to fight systemic injustice Madeleine Conn, ArdrishaigSir,The SNP continues to demonstrate its economic incompetence.New figures show the SNP government underspent its budget by a quarter of a billion pounds in -, and failed to use £ million of borrowing capacity. ​Instead of demanding further borrowing powers and more funding from the UK Government, the separatists should learn to use the resources they already have.With such colossal mismanagement, it#s no surprise that even senior SNP advisor Andrew Wilson has stated that Scotland is set to be the worst performing economy in the developed world. Once again, the separatists# numbers simply don#t add up.Councillor Alastair Redman # Kintyre and Islands wardSir,Exactly two years ago I was diagnosed with stage three, oestrogen positive breast cancer.I’d just come back from a week#s holiday in Spain with Isabel and Margaret. Days before I went on holiday I’d had a biopsy following referral from my GP. Although there wasn’t a cloud in the sky, my holiday was definitely clouded by impending results#I had chosen to wait until after my holiday to get them.The journey that Monday to go to Gartnavel is one I’ll never forget. My partner Frank didn’t shut up the whole way there, obviously he was nervous. I couldn’t be bothered with the small talk and just wanted him to shut up. Obviously I was nervous and he was just trying to keep my mind off it, but I was too busy silently praying. The number  is something I see all the time so I spent the whole journey looking for the number on someone’s licence plate #I saw it everything would be ok. I didn#t see it. That might sound a bit daft, but fear does crazy things to you.Walking into the consultant#s room and finding a nurse waiting there confirmed my worst fears. #It’s a wee cancer,# said Mr Wilson. The words echoing in my head, I couldn’t hear anything after that. I remember taking a deep breath and looking at Frank. I will never, ever forget the look on his face.My only question that day was #am I going to lose my breasts # The answer was no, and thankfully Frank was there to take in what was being said my head was spinning. The question I really wanted to ask was #am I going to die # I was too scared to ask that question.I didn’t cry until I walked out the hospital, then I bawled. Frank was amazing, and he didn’t talk like a budgie on the way home.The journey home was horrendous. I was terried about telling my mum. How do you tell your mum that her only child has cancer  I hadn’t told her anything about finding a lump. I couldn’t cope with worrying about her worrying about me # butit happens again I#d do it dferently and she’ll be the first to know. By the time I got home I had no more tears left.The relief telling mum was a huge weight off my shoulders. What ensued after my initial diagnosis was two weeks of crying every day. Telling the girls at work was so emotional, and in fact I was exhausted with it all.Once surgery and treatment plans were in place I was in a better place. Time to get the head down and get on with it, and that#s what I did. I was full of positivity and determination, and I think my sense of humour helped enormously.The treatment was bad, but it was necessary. The ongoing treatment is bad but it#s necessary. I’m alive and that’s what matters. My le has changed forever, nothing will be the same. My le has been ided into Before Cancer and After Cancer  I now have a new #normal#.I don’t know what the future holds, who does, but I intend to live my le happily, positively and most definitely to the fullest!I will never forget the support, both physically and emotionally that I received from my nearest and dearest, and of course from the whole community. The strength you have given me continues, and for that I am truly grateful.Please, pleaseyou find an abnormality or you just feel something isn’t quite right, act upon it and seek attention.I know it’s a dficult time with this horrid virus but it’s important to remember that early detection saves lives.Stay safe and take care.Yvie Young, Lochgilphead
